bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 23, 1945

div1.p: Kean comments on his future travel plans. He extends an invitation to Hench to study his personal papers.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, November 23, 1945

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
23 Nov. '45

div1.p:
Your last letter of Oct. 14 was rec'd
on the 18th and gave me the good
news that you would be relieved from
duty at Hot Springs about Nov 10
and go on a round of inspections
of what they were doing at certain
other General Hospitals. Then you
would return to Hot Springs, pack up,
and drive home where you would see
the family & leave the car, coming
here in Dec to make your report &
return home for Christmas, I hope
you arranged your program so you would
be home for thanksgiving and that you
are there now to see what the Army boy
Ac
K
2
could do to the drumstick of a turkey
yesterday- I wrote to you on 9th Nov. that
the Governors of the Club had ruled
that rooms at the Club could not be
let to non-members on Cards, in
view of the demand for them by the
members coming home from service
abroad- But our upstairs locataires
have now departed and we can
put you up here with us- Our
house keeping is however of a light
order with a part-time cook and
dinner at 1 oclock with only soup
and wine in the evening, so a good
trencher man like you would probably
prefer to get a real dinner down town.
You will have a fine quiet upstairs
to do your work however and we
will love to have you under our roof
I would love to have you rummage thru
3
my disorderly files of papers and
take any of them which you
would want- We had last Mon-
day the annual meeting of the Walter
Reed Memorial Assn. I am not sure
that I have ever told you of that
very select self-perpetuating body.
It was a group of Walter Reeds admir-
ers who after his death raised a
fund of $25,000 for a monument to
him. But the interest was to be given
to Mrs Reed during her life time
and to Blossom Reed there after for
her life- Of course Mrs Reed has her
pension of $125.00 a month and a
quite handsome additional sum given
by an unknown donor so she has been
well taken care of- Mr. Bell President
in 1903 of the American Security & Trust Co
took a great interest in this fund and for
his life time was the Treasurer- I am the
Ac
K
4
only living one of the original group of Incorpo
rators, or Managers as they are now
called, of the fund which is now about
$35,000 and am the President. Gen.
Ireland is V. P. and Col Siler is the
Secy- The Treasurer is always an
officer of the Amer. Security & Trust Co.
His name is Ireland but no relation
to our friend- There were 21 Incorpo-
rators but all the vacancies have not
been filled- A vacancy occurred two
days before our last meeting and
you were elected to fill it- There are
no dues or duties, except for the
officers, and attendance at the annual
meeting if in Washington- The date is on
the date of death of Walter Reed-
We regard it as quite an honor, and
there is no doubt that you have earned
it among the Managers present who
5
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON 7, D. C.
voted unanimously for your election-
I am sending you herewith the only
printed matter which there has ever
been in connection with this Corporate
body- It was put together by me to
be sent with a letter signed by
Gen. George M. Sternberg, asking for
contributions, to a small group
who contributed the fund-

You can see the sort of men that ad-
mired Reed from the list of Incor-
porators- And I am sure that you
will value this ancient document

Hoping to hear from you soon I
am always
